AUTUMN LACROSSE
PRACTICE ENDS
Practice for lacrosse has
been suspended until next
spring because of inclement
weather conditions. Manager
Carroll wants every man who
has university equipment
charged against him to return
the same to either himself or
to Junior Manager William
Banks, who will be at Homewood field locker room tomorrow afternoon. Men who
have personal equipment at
the field should also procure
it at this time.

FIRST COTILLON
RESULTS IN DEFICIT
One hundred and twentyone dollars was lost by the
Cotillon Club on the first Cotillon held on December 2.
Due to this deficit the Club
will hold no more dances until after the holidays, according to Kenneth Proctor, one
of its members. The amount
lost will have to be made up
at the Saturday night dances
after the first of the new year.

WHAT PRICE TRADITION?
A few weeks ago it chanc0 to be our lot to fall in for a few
minutes with a University of Maryland student. The College
Parker was, of course, very enthusiastic about Maryland. He
discussed the events that had led to his enrolling at Maryland,
saying, in part:
"My father went down. to the University with me to look the
place over; wherever we went we were greeted by the students.
My father turned to me and said: 'This is a mighty fine place.
When I was at college the boys never spoke to anybody but their
friends.' That was, perhaps, my main reason for deciding to go
to U. of M."
One of the oldest traditions at Hopkins is that of saying "Hello"
to all persons met on the campus. In view of the small amount
of dormitory life here, the preservation of the tradition is rendered more.difficult. If we are to cultivate a real Hopkins spirit,
it is up to every one of us to speak to friend and stranger alike.
During the past year failure to speak to other men passed on the
campus has been increasingly glaring. Are we too lazy or too
snobbish to speak to those we don't know?
Let's say "Hello!"
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation
George S. Hill as assistant photographer.

FIRST DORMITORY DANCE OF YEAR
CALLED GREAT SUCCESS BY RESIDENTS
The first dormitory dance of the
year was both a social and financial
success. The entertainment committee wishes to thank the residents
for their noble support. The committee is encouraged and promises
bigger and better dances in the
future. The music was furnished
by the Simpson-Morris orchestra
and was excellent.
The stag line was. Impregnable.
A whole fleet of them invaded the
dance following the Musical Club
concert. A fellow was unable to
proceed farther than the first few
phrases of his line before he was
attacked.

"PROFS" FLAYED

tory I and "Wop," known in the
catalogue as Italian I. Now this
year those grinning, fiendish, diabolical souls who direct our courses
have lain traps for the unsuspecting
student who, busy with other work,
signs up for one of these courses
for an easy six •points. I believe
that we are the victims of a deep
and well-laid plot that has reached
its culmination after years of preparatory effort. These courses have
been easy in the past merely to lure
us on for this great coup d'etat of
those who write grades in red ink.
Alas and alack they have succeeded
so completely that Italian I and
History I now hold their own with
that demon, Physics. What is our
University coming to? One more
old tradition gone the way of all
flesh.

Members of the football team will
gather at the Southern Hotel tomorrow evening at seven o'clock for
their annual banquet. For the first
time in the history of the football
dinners, alumni have been invited
to attend. . Iii former years the banquet has been closed to members of
the team and representatives of the
local newspapers. About a hundred
and twenty-five persons are expected to attend tomorrow, according
to Manager Bauernschmidt.
A number of prep school stars
have also been invited, including
Buck Miller, Helm, Goldberg of
City College; Morrison of Forest
Park and McCullough of Poly.
"Pop" Swindell will officiate as
toastmaster and Coach Van Orman
will be the principal speaker. All
lettermen will be awarded miniature gold footballs. Following the
banquet, there will be a dance from
ten to one. Attendance will be
limited by cards of invitation. Each
member of the team has been given
three invitations to distribute among.
friends. These cards, when presented with a dollar, will admit
the bearers to the dance.

The basketball team that is never satisfied with
its performance is headed for the top. And in
this, as in the making of telephone apparatus,
success follows from the determination of every
man to cover his position and work in harmony

At Western Electric, a continually widening

for manufacture,studying operating methods and
personnel relations—any one of which offers the
individual an interesting field.

contribution to its success depend upon his acceptance of this Western Electric idea: to improve
the machinery of production to a point where
it more closely approaches perfection.

DEAN WHITEHEAD SPEAKS

•
Engineering Head Lectures at Assembly on French Colleges
•Gustave Werner, Jr., Ferdinand
Schmiedicke, John Bruening, Robert Lang and William Russell were
Publicly initiated into Tau Beta Pi,
at last Thursday's Assembly. Dean
Whitehead of the Engineering
School delivered the address, while
-r --thelatte-r-part-of-the assembly was
devoted to a matter somewhat foreign to the former, namely, basketball.

I

Loane Takes Charge

Edward S. Loane, president of
'Ian Beta Pi, opened the assembly
With a brief talk on the selection of
men to be honored by membership
in the fraternity. Although excellent scholarship is a necessary requirement other qualifications are
considered. Chief among these are
integrity and interest in affairs affecting both engineering and other
fields. The secretary read out the
names of the elected men. From
the senior class were elected two
Civil Engineering students, one Mechanical and one Electrical; while
from the junior class, one Chemical.

Interesting slides showing the
modern trend of automatic clinking machines were shown at a meeting of the Gas Engineering Association. The lecture was attended by
quite a large number, incruding Dr.
Huff of the Engineering School.
Mr. Kuns of the Western Gas
Co. presented the slides and described the new methods. The devices have been tried out at the
Spring Garden Plant of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and
Power Co., the new machines being
installed by the Western Gas Construction Co.
The slides included many pictures
of the old and archaic means of
removing clinkers from the old type
gas manufacturing furnaces. The
new contrivances, by means of
which ash is automatically removed,
are very ingenious.

Dr. Greenlaw to
Address Club
Professor Edwin Greenlaw will
address the History of Ideas Club at
a meeting to be held Thursday evening at 8 o'clock.
The subject of Dr. Greenlaw's
talk will be "The Sixteenth Century
Battle of the Book." Members of
the faculty and graduate students
are cordially invited to attend this
meeting.

INANE RAMBLINGS
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
Every year, someone always rises
to smite the younger generations, its
standards, moral •and spiritual; and
again some other person, fired by
their insinuations, steps forth and
takes a stand in defense. So much
for the cause of this.
Several weeks ago, Stephen Leacock published in one of Baltimore's so-called reflective newspapers an article entitled "A Cycle
of Love." If the author's purpose
was to be funny, then it was a success. If he desired to create an
impression other than one as a jokester, then it was a failure.
John M. Smith, the hero of this
attempt to fill the columns, is described as a modern college boy who
after ten years of collegiate work
or life, had one better say, received
a slip of paper which entitled him
to become divorced several times,
and to participate into other devilish practices. While there are John
M. Smiths, there are also John
Smiths, and we are to believe that
the •college man has thrown all
standards to the winds and is following an unwritten code of his
own.
The hero is depicted as a devil
who loved 'e mand left 'em—they,
pining for his return—he, looking
for other worlds to conquer.
Abigail Price, the heroine, is described as .one of those souls that
are true to the end, often referred
to as being "all wool and a yard
wide." She just loved to pine and
then the cycle begins again.
However, we must admit that the
present day youth are hell bent!
This business of going to cotillons
is bad dope, no doubt, and to smoke
a pipe and in continuance of this
warning process to wear a raccoon
coat is inexcusable.
"And don't you know, Nora,
D'Alti came home with red paint
in his hair last Saturday." Oh!
my—what shall we do?
Well, boys, let's stick together
and smoke our pipes besides engaging in other sorts of badness and
remember to be just as determined
as Hah-vahd is in its Princetonian
struggle. Repulse their insinuations
and, above all, be oh! so determined.
CAUSTIC CHARLES.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 13, 1927

6

THE BARNSTORMERS WILL
DR. WOOD TO ADDRESS EVIDENTLY
KEEP THEIR MYSTERY PLAY MYSTERIOUS
DAY
ASSEMBLYITERS
Mystery! Detectives! Melodrama! As a last hope, two star NEWSRenowned Light-Physicist Is Engaged in Research
"High Frequency Sound Waves"
will be the subject of Dr. Wood's
address to the assembly next Thursday. Dr. Wood, a world renowned
light-physicist and authority on ultra-violet and infra-red light, is actively engaged at research here in
the physics department. At present he is studying the iodine vapor
spectrum and has written many
treatises of scientific interest on
these subjects.
Attention was first called to high
frequency sound waves shortly
after the war while experimenting
on devices for the detection of submarines by reflected sound. The
peculiar effects were noted on fish
in the experimental tanks, but no
extensive research was done until
the publication of a thesis on this
work by Dr. Wood.
Dr. Wood had conducted these
researches in the laboratory of Dr.
Alfred Loomis, his co-worker, in
their laboratory at Tuxedo, New
York.
World-Wide Interest

Immediately these experiments
attracted world-wide interest, because of the unique physical and
biological effects of these high frequency, high intensity sound waves.
Dr. Wood will illustrate some of
these curious phenomena with
slides.
During the war Dr. Wood, himself, was employed in an interesting
research. His specialty was the
adaption of invisible infra-red rays
for signalling.

Beautiful heroine! Manly hero!
What? The Barnstormers' play.
"Is that all that you will tell about
your coming mystery mystery play,
Mr. Warfield?" the president of the
Barnstormers was asked.
"Absolutely all," Warfield answered. "It is a first-class mystery
play, comprising all the elements of
suspense, curiosity, comedy and
drama. You will have to wait until
February to find out more about it."
Further questioning proved absolutely futile. Warfield would tell
nothing more about the play chosen
by the Barnstormers.
Douglas Prahl, business manager
of the Dramatic Club, was questioned as to the name or even the
author of presentation. He begged
all questions very cleverly by talking of the business outlook of the
club for the coming season. Very
bright, indeed; but that's not what
information was wanted from him.
A trip to the Dormitory to question Jerome Nott also proved fruitless. On entering his room he was
seen to seize a small brown booklet
and slam his desk drawer closed
with amazing alacrity. This was
secrecy with a vengeance.
"But why all this secrecy and
mystery, Jerry ?" our exasperated
reporter finally asked.
"Well, you see it's this way,"
Nott began, and immediately two
disgruntled reporters stalked out of
the room and slammed the door.
Bribery, wheedling, trickery,
everything failed. The Barnstormers were determined. Not even the
candidates could be made to speak.

Playshop to Revive
American Comedy.

This year the Homewood Playshop is considering the production
of either a series of plays representing the history of American Comedy or a group of original plays.
Mr. John Ely, who is the new director, will be in charge of these
productions. The financial obligations of the Playshop have been
removed by the payment of the
amount advanced on the part of
the University Trustees for the
construction of the little theatre.
and with this burden removed the
members will be able to devote their
energies to this year's plays.
Plans are only in the tentative
stage at present, but in case they
decide to reproduce the American
Comedy, the players have considered reviving Royal Tyler's "Contrast." So far as has been determined, this is its first revival. "Contrast" is the first American Comedy,
and was written in 1787. Tyler,
so the story runs,'had been reared
very strictly and had not seen any
play. However, while on military
service in New York, he saw
"School for Scandal" being played
there. It delighted him. Under
its influence he wrote "Contrast,"
which was well received and published in 1790. Thus the first
American Comedy was decidedly
impromptu in its origin. This play
is also noteworthy because it creates
the "typical Yankee" type. The
hostility of the province to the metropolis is one of its chief themes,
and it is of great historical interest
as a guide to the social conditions
of the period. This season the
Playshop will adhere to its policy of
scholarly instruction rather th2n
entertainment.

SAMUEL KIRK & SON, INc.

One hundred and twentyone dollars was lost by the
Cotillon Club on the first Cotillon held on December 2.

will hold no more dances until after the holidays, according to Kenneth Proctor, one

lost will have to be made up
at the Saturday night dances
after the first of the new year.

WHAT PRICE TRADITION?
A few weeks ago it chanc0 to be our lot to fall in for a few
minutes with a University of Maryland student. The College
Parker was, of course, very enthusiastic about Maryland. He
discussed the events that had led to his enrolling at Maryland,
saying, in part:
"My father went down. to the University with me to look the
place over; wherever we went we were greeted by the students.
My father turned to me and said: 'This is a mighty fine place.
When I was at college the boys never spoke to anybody but their
friends.' That was, perhaps, my main reason for deciding to go
to U. of M."
One of the oldest traditions at Hopkins is that of saying "Hello"
to all persons met on the campus. In view of the small amount
of dormitory life here, the preservation of the tradition is rendered more.difficult. If we are to cultivate a real Hopkins spirit,
it is up to every one of us to speak to friend and stranger alike.
During the past year failure to speak to other men passed on the
campus has been increasingly glaring. Are we too lazy or too
snobbish to speak to those we don't know?
Let's say "Hello!"

"PROFS" FLAYED

tory I and "Wop," known in the
catalogue as Italian I. Now this
year those grinning, fiendish, diabolical souls who direct our courses
have lain traps for the unsuspecting
student who, busy with other work,
signs up for one of these courses
for an easy six •points. I believe
that we are the victims of a deep
and well-laid plot that has reached
its culmination after years of preparatory effort. These courses have
been easy in the past merely to lure
us on for this great coup d'etat of
those who write grades in red ink.
Alas and alack they have succeeded
so completely that Italian I and
History I now hold their own with
that demon, Physics. What is our
University coming to? One more
old tradition gone the way of all
flesh.
SOCRATES (Himself).

Football Banquet
Tomorrow Night
Dance at Civil Engineering Hall to
Follow Grid Dinner at
Southern

au Jo gei More
Mileage fro

Members of the football team will
gather at the Southern Hotel tomorrow evening at seven o'clock for
their annual banquet. For the first
time in the history of the football
dinners, alumni have been invited
to attend. . Iii former years the banquet has been closed to members of
the team and representatives of the
local newspapers. About a hundred
and twenty-five persons are expected to attend tomorrow, according
to Manager Bauernschmidt.
A number of prep school stars
have also been invited, including
Buck Miller, Helm, Goldberg of
City College; Morrison of Forest
Park and McCullough of Poly.
"Pop" Swindell will officiate as
toastmaster and Coach Van Orman
will be the principal speaker. All
lettermen will be awarded miniature gold footballs. Following the
banquet, there will be a dance from
ten to one. Attendance will be
limited by cards of invitation. Each
member of the team has been given
three invitations to distribute among.
friends. These cards, when presented with a dollar, will admit
the bearers to the dance.

Where "good enough" isn't
The basketball team that is never satisfied with
its performance is headed for the top. And in
this, as in the making of telephone apparatus,
success follows from the determination of every
man to cover his position and work in harmony
with his team mates.
At Western Electric, a continually widening
range of activities is being undertaken—for example, investigating raw materials, designing
more efficient machinery, developing new plans
for manufacture,studying operating methods and
personnel relations—any one of which offers the
individual an interesting field.
But whatever the work, his place in it and his
contribution to its success depend upon his acceptance of this Western Electric idea: to improve
the machinery of production to a point where
it more closely approaches perfection.

FIVE MEN TAKEN Gas Engineers
Showing of Slides
INTO TAU BETA PI
Werner, Schmiedicke„ Bruening
Lang, and Russell Initiated
DEAN WHITEHEAD SPEAKS

•
Engineering Head Lectures at Assembly on French Colleges
•Gustave Werner, Jr., Ferdinand
Schmiedicke, John Bruening, Robert Lang and William Russell were
Publicly initiated into Tau Beta Pi,
at last Thursday's Assembly. Dean
Whitehead of the Engineering
School delivered the address, while
-r --thelatte-r-part-of-the assembly was
devoted to a matter somewhat foreign to the former, namely, basketball.

I

Loane Takes Charge

Edward S. Loane, president of
'Ian Beta Pi, opened the assembly
With a brief talk on the selection of
men to be honored by membership
in the fraternity. Although excellent scholarship is a necessary requirement other qualifications are
considered. Chief among these are
integrity and interest in affairs affecting both engineering and other
fields. The secretary read out the
names of the elected men. From
the senior class were elected two
Civil Engineering students, one Mechanical and one Electrical; while
from the junior class, one Chemical.

Interesting slides showing the
modern trend of automatic clinking machines were shown at a meeting of the Gas Engineering Association. The lecture was attended by
quite a large number, incruding Dr.
Huff of the Engineering School.
Mr. Kuns of the Western Gas
Co. presented the slides and described the new methods. The devices have been tried out at the
Spring Garden Plant of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and
Power Co., the new machines being
installed by the Western Gas Construction Co.
The slides included many pictures
of the old and archaic means of
removing clinkers from the old type
gas manufacturing furnaces. The
new contrivances, by means of
which ash is automatically removed,
are very ingenious.

Dr. Greenlaw to
Address Club
Professor Edwin Greenlaw will
address the History of Ideas Club at
a meeting to be held Thursday evening at 8 o'clock.
The subject of Dr. Greenlaw's
talk will be "The Sixteenth Century
Battle of the Book." Members of
the faculty and graduate students
are cordially invited to attend this
meeting.

INANE RAMBLINGS
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
Every year, someone always rises
to smite the younger generations, its
standards, moral •and spiritual; and
again some other person, fired by
their insinuations, steps forth and
takes a stand in defense. So much
for the cause of this.
Several weeks ago, Stephen Leacock published in one of Baltimore's so-called reflective newspapers an article entitled "A Cycle
of Love." If the author's purpose
was to be funny, then it was a success. If he desired to create an
impression other than one as a jokester, then it was a failure.
John M. Smith, the hero of this
attempt to fill the columns, is described as a modern college boy who
after ten years of collegiate work
or life, had one better say, received
a slip of paper which entitled him
to become divorced several times,
and to participate into other devilish practices. While there are John
M. Smiths, there are also John
Smiths, and we are to believe that
the •college man has thrown all
standards to the winds and is following an unwritten code of his
own.
The hero is depicted as a devil
who loved 'e mand left 'em—they,
pining for his return—he, looking
for other worlds to conquer.
Abigail Price, the heroine, is described as .one of those souls that
are true to the end, often referred
to as being "all wool and a yard
wide." She just loved to pine and
then the cycle begins again.
However, we must admit that the
present day youth are hell bent!
This business of going to cotillons
is bad dope, no doubt, and to smoke
a pipe and in continuance of this
warning process to wear a raccoon
coat is inexcusable.
"And don't you know, Nora,
D'Alti came home with red paint
in his hair last Saturday." Oh!
my—what shall we do?
Well, boys, let's stick together
and smoke our pipes besides engaging in other sorts of badness and
remember to be just as determined
as Hah-vahd is in its Princetonian
struggle. Repulse their insinuations
and, above all, be oh! so determined.
CAUSTIC CHARLES.

ASSEMBLYITERS
Mystery! Detectives! Melodrama! As a last hope, two star NEWSRenowned Light-Physicist Is Engaged in Research
"High Frequency Sound Waves"
will be the subject of Dr. Wood's
address to the assembly next Thursday. Dr. Wood, a world renowned
light-physicist and authority on ultra-violet and infra-red light, is actively engaged at research here in
the physics department. At present he is studying the iodine vapor
spectrum and has written many
treatises of scientific interest on
these subjects.
Attention was first called to high
frequency sound waves shortly
after the war while experimenting
on devices for the detection of submarines by reflected sound. The
peculiar effects were noted on fish
in the experimental tanks, but no
extensive research was done until
the publication of a thesis on this
work by Dr. Wood.
Dr. Wood had conducted these
researches in the laboratory of Dr.
Alfred Loomis, his co-worker, in
their laboratory at Tuxedo, New
York.
World-Wide Interest

Immediately these experiments
attracted world-wide interest, because of the unique physical and
biological effects of these high frequency, high intensity sound waves.
Dr. Wood will illustrate some of
these curious phenomena with
slides.
During the war Dr. Wood, himself, was employed in an interesting
research. His specialty was the
adaption of invisible infra-red rays
for signalling.

Beautiful heroine! Manly hero!
What? The Barnstormers' play.
"Is that all that you will tell about
your coming mystery mystery play,
Mr. Warfield?" the president of the
Barnstormers was asked.
"Absolutely all," Warfield answered. "It is a first-class mystery
play, comprising all the elements of
suspense, curiosity, comedy and
drama. You will have to wait until
February to find out more about it."
Further questioning proved absolutely futile. Warfield would tell
nothing more about the play chosen
by the Barnstormers.
Douglas Prahl, business manager
of the Dramatic Club, was questioned as to the name or even the
author of presentation. He begged
all questions very cleverly by talking of the business outlook of the
club for the coming season. Very
bright, indeed; but that's not what
information was wanted from him.
A trip to the Dormitory to question Jerome Nott also proved fruitless. On entering his room he was
seen to seize a small brown booklet
and slam his desk drawer closed
with amazing alacrity. This was
secrecy with a vengeance.
"But why all this secrecy and
mystery, Jerry ?" our exasperated
reporter finally asked.
"Well, you see it's this way,"
Nott began, and immediately two
disgruntled reporters stalked out of
the room and slammed the door.
Bribery, wheedling, trickery,
everything failed. The Barnstormers were determined. Not even the
candidates could be made to speak.

Playshop to Revive
American Comedy.

This year the Homewood Playshop is considering the production
of either a series of plays representing the history of American Comedy or a group of original plays.
Mr. John Ely, who is the new director, will be in charge of these
productions. The financial obligations of the Playshop have been
removed by the payment of the
amount advanced on the part of
the University Trustees for the
construction of the little theatre.
and with this burden removed the
members will be able to devote their
energies to this year's plays.
Plans are only in the tentative
stage at present, but in case they
decide to reproduce the American
Comedy, the players have considered reviving Royal Tyler's "Contrast." So far as has been determined, this is its first revival. "Contrast" is the first American Comedy,
and was written in 1787. Tyler,
so the story runs,'had been reared
very strictly and had not seen any
play. However, while on military
service in New York, he saw
"School for Scandal" being played
there. It delighted him. Under
its influence he wrote "Contrast,"
which was well received and published in 1790. Thus the first
American Comedy was decidedly
impromptu in its origin. This play
is also noteworthy because it creates
the "typical Yankee" type. The
hostility of the province to the metropolis is one of its chief themes,
and it is of great historical interest
as a guide to the social conditions
of the period. This season the
Playshop will adhere to its policy of
scholarly instruction rather th2n
entertainment.

SAMUEL KIRK & SON, INc.
